title: Sigmoid Volvulus in Elderly Patient
setup_script: An 80-year-old nursing home resident presents with abdominal distension and pain. She has not passed stool or flatus for 24 hours. X-ray shows a coffee-bean sign consistent with sigmoid volvulus.

dynamic_flow.trigger: Assess history of constipation, psychiatric medications, neurologic disorders, and previous episodes of volvulus.
Perform physical exam noting distension, tympany, and signs of peritonitis; check vital signs for sepsis.
Order labs including CBC, electrolytes, and lactate; obtain abdominal X-ray and CT to confirm volvulus and exclude perforation.
Initial management: resuscitate with IV fluids, correct electrolytes, and decompress with rectal tube via flexible sigmoidoscopy.
Explain success rates of endoscopic detorsion and the need for rectal tube to prevent recurrence.
Evaluate for signs of ischemia or perforation (fever, leukocytosis, peritonitis) that warrant emergent surgery.
If endoscopic decompression fails or signs of ischemia develop, plan for emergent sigmoidectomy with primary anastomosis or Hartmann's procedure.
Obtain informed consent and discuss risk of recurrence and mortality in elderly patients.
Perform sigmoid colectomy; decide on primary anastomosis versus end colostomy based on patient stability and colon viability.
Postoperative care: monitor for sepsis, anastomotic leak, and ileus; advance diet slowly.
Arrange follow-up with gastroenterology and nutrition services; discuss risk reduction including bowel regimen and mobility.
Educate family about signs of recurrence and when to seek urgent care.

critical_decision_points: Prompt recognition of volvulus and initial endoscopic detorsion.
Identification of ischemia requiring emergent surgery.
Decision between primary anastomosis and Hartmann's based on patient's condition.
Postoperative management in elderly with comorbidities.
